refnamediv.refpurpose: common options to manage internationalization in OCaml program.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This manual page documents briefly the common options provided by programs using ocaml-gettext library.

listitem.para:
Defines the behavior of ocaml-gettext regarding any errors that could be encounter during the processing of string translation. By default, errors are ignored and the string returned is the original string untranslated. This behavior is consistent and allow to have a usable output, even if it is not perfect. Choices are :
ignore : default behavior, return an untranslated string,
inform-stderr : same behavior as ignore, expect that a message is printed on stderr,
raise-exception : stop the program by raising an exception.
Disable any translation made by ocaml-gettext. All translation returns the original string untranslated.
Defines a dir to search for a specific domain. This could be useful if MO file are stored in a non standard directory.
Add a directory to search for MO file.

Set the language to use in ocaml-gettext library. The language should be POSIX compliant. The language should follow the following convention : lang[_territory][.charset][@modifier]. The lang should be a two letter ISO code. The territory should be also a two letter ISO code. Charset should be a valid ISO character set ( at least recognized by the underlying charset recoding routine ). For example, valid language should be : fr_FR.ISO-8859-1@euro, de_DE.UTF-8.
Set the codeset the default codeset for output.

refsect1.para: User should be aware that this command line option, only apply for strings after the initialization of the library. This means that if the options initally guessed by ocaml-gettext, there should be some untranslated string, because these strings are translated before parsing the option. This is particulary true for the usage message itself ( --help ) : even if the strings are translated, they are translated before parsing the option ( because they describe the option to apply ).

Some options ( --gettext-codeset for example ) are overrided internaly for particular use. For example, it should be required to always translate strings to UTF-8 in graphical user interface ( because GTK2 requires it ).
